awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Modeling Response-Time Distributions to Test Theories of Event Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Memory for previously experienced events can take many forms, such as deciding whether a person's face was seen previously versus deciding where a person's face was seen previously. Different theories make different assumptions about how these various forms of memory come about. Whereas some theories assume that the ability to call to mind a prior experience is all-or-none (it either occurs or does not), other theories assume that bits of information accumulate in a continuous manner from less to more. Yet other theories assume that both an all-or-none ability to call something to mind and a process of continuously accumulating information co-exist, and either mechanism can underlie memory in a given situation (it is a matter of teasing them apart). Determining the true state of affairs is important for a number of reasons, including the development of appropriate methods for assessing eyewitness memory, the development of appropriate tools for assessing cognitive functions in cases of memory impairment, and the development of appropriate memory tasks for use in research on the neural underpinnings of memory. 

This CAREER project by an early career stage investigator aims to differentiate among existing models of human event memory by imposing constraints not typically used by researchers. Previous modeling efforts have led to somewhat of an impasse regarding understanding human event memory because vastly different models are all able to accommodate human data patterns produced in empirical studies of how memory accuracy varies across experimental conditions. In addition to the typically-used accuracy measures of memory, this project will use response time measures to further constrain the data needing to be accommodated by the models in order to better force differentiation among the possible theoretical alternatives. Across a number of experiments, various experimental manipulations will be used in conjunction with these measures to provide even further constraints to help to rule models out and potentially identify a candidate model for how human event memory most likely operates. As part of the education component of the CAREER plan, the investigator will create a computational modeling concentration within the Psychology major, providing undergraduate students with a unique opportunity to develop cognitive modeling skills. He will also make the modeling tools from the research available to the research community via a website.

por.por_cntn:
Memory for specific events can take various forms, including recognition judgments (i.e., deciding whether or not a stimulus was previously encountered) and source judgments (i.e., choosing the specific context in which a stimulus was encountered from multiple options). The question "Did you see Bill at work yesterday?" requires a recognition judgment, whereas "Did you meet Susan in high school or college?" requires a source judgment. A notable aspect of these judgments is that they require a decision process: one must evaluate evidence retrieved from memory (e.g., "I remember playing softball with Susan") and assess this evidence to make a conclusion (e.g., "I must have known Susan from high school"). Theorists have proposed a variety of mathematical models describing how memory evidence is translated into recognition and source decisions. Testing these models helps researchers understand the basic processes that support memory decisions, and improving the models improves the ability to accurately measure memory performance.  

The primary aim of this project was to test decision models using both response time (RT) and response proportion data. Response proportion data are often summarized as a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC), a function that relates the probability of making a correct response to the probability of making an error response. One model under consideration was the diffusion model, which assumes that retrieval produces continuous outcomes. These outcomes are often characterized as "strength" values representing how well a test item matches memory for the studied items. Evidence from these outcomes is accumulated over time until the evidence reaches a threshold value. Signal detection theory (SDT) models also assume a continuous retrieval process, but with a "one-shot" retrieval attempt instead of evidence accumulated over many attempts. Other models assume discrete retrieval states, with retrieval either recovering accurate memories or failing to produce any information. For example, the two-high-threshold (2HT) model proposes that all retrieval is discrete, and the dual process signal detection (DPSD) model proposes a mixture of discrete and continuous retrieval states from separate memory systems.

A key component of achieving the project aims was developing a new model of the discrete retrieval process. The new model accommodates RT distributions and has a mechanism for the speed-accuracy tradeoff, the finding that making decisions under time pressure reduces accuracy. Code implementing this model is freely available to other researchers in a public repository, enhancing the information infrastructure for future research efforts. This new model introduces new ways to test discrete retrieval models against continuous retrieval models of RT data, like the diffusion model.

Research activity for this project produced a number of discoveries that elucidate the decision processes involved in memory tasks and distinguish alternative models of decision making. Consistent with models proposing continuous retrieval states, several of the discoveries show that misleading retrieval is a fundamental aspect of recognition memory. That is, even in normal tasks with no special trickery from the experimenter, people sometimes retrieve clear evidence that they experienced an event even though they did not, and vice versa. A number of project findings support this conclusion. For example, making a retrieval attempt can actually impair memory performance when participants see cues that indicate which answer is likely to be correct on a given trial. This result shows that misleading memory retrieval can override the useful evidence from the cue. Results also indicated that errors based on convincing misleading evidence tend to be made quickly, as revealed by the fact that participants tend to report higher confidence in fast than slow errors and the fact that they are less likely to be able to later correct a fast error than a slow error. All of these phenomena were well described by decision models with continuous retrieval (e.g., the diffusion model), but they could not be accommodated by a 2HT model, which does not have a mechanism for misleading retrieval.

Other studies showed that simultaneously evaluating RT distributions, the speed-accuracy tradeoff, and ROCs in a recognition task also supports continuous-retrieval models over the 2HT model; that biasing manipulations result in both faster decisions and faster motor execution of responses; and that the shape of source memory ROCs is not based on source recollection, as assumed by the DPSD model. The project also led to the discovery of a new way to characterize memory classification performance, Expected Information Gain, and showed how understanding the memory decision process can help to optimize the use of eyewitness evidence in criminal investigations.

Training activities included establishing a concentration in cognitive modeling for undergraduate students, which expanded educational opportunities in terms of available courses and research mentoring. The project created many research opportunities at the graduate and undergraduate levels, and recruitment for research assistants was coordinated with the Advancing Diversity in Research and Practice (ADRAP) program.
